subSubSection.paragraph:
Dallas ( 1851 )
was the first reviser and synonymized three of Westwood’s species (
frontalis , capicola
and
lata
), choosing
capicola
as the valid name even though frontali s had page priority (
ICNZ 1999
, Articles 24 a and 24 b).

Diagnosis. Thorax: ostiolar ruga long, but shorter than in
N. orbiculata
, anterior margin curved, apex pointed (
Fig. 3
D
). Abdomen: urosternites with black maculae, diameter shorter than spiracles, as in
N. orbiculata .
Male: ventral rim of pygophore with brims developed towards middle, not continuous at mid line, and forming a deep concavity there (
Fig. 8
G
), character exclusive for this species; paramere trilobate, lobes rounded and slightly developed. Female: posterior margins of gonocoxites 8 straight; basal half of laterotergites 9 laterally concave and medially convex (
Fig. 16
G
); ductus receptaculi, after vesicular area, longer than three times the length of pars intermedialis (
Fig. 18
B
), shared with
N. orbiculata
and
N. soror .

caption.paragraph:
